title: asking about _.difference
body: Hi all. Iam using _.difference with two variables but got different result if i swap the argument. Here the example. ``` var a = [1,2,3,4]; var b = [1,2,3,4,5]; console.log(_.difference(a,b)) // got [] console.log(_.difference(b,a)) // got [5] ``` Is that normal? So i need put the longest variable as the first arguments? i use 3.10.0

title: first() is no longer chainable
body:
In the previous version _([1, 2, 3]).first(2)
return a lodash chainable object

but now it returns 1.

title: _.floor() seems to not floor correctly with precision
body:
Seems to be an issue with certain numbers, for instance:

``` javascript
_.floor( 8888.88, 2 )  // --> 8888.87
```

Chrome 46, Safari 8

title: _.random should use the CSPRNG when available
body:
`_.random` should use the CSPRNG when available, and default to `Math.random` when it isn't available.

```
crypto.getRandomValues(new Uint8Array(1))[0]
// 162
```

title: .get nested object with dot in key
body:
``` bash
## works
> get({ 'some.field': 123 }, 'some.field') 
123

## works
> get({some: {field: 123}}, 'some.field');
123

## This is the one I'm trying to use and doesn't work
> get({some: {'nested.field': 123}}, 'some.nested.field');
undefined

## This doesn't work either
> get({'some.nested': {field: 123}}, 'some.nested.field');
undefined
```

title: Lazy optimization for `at`
body:
When using `at` to pull specific indexes from an array mapped using lazy evaluation (and maybe other operations too), it seems like we're missing the potential for more optimizations

```
var testFixture = [];

Object.defineProperty(testFixture, '0', { get() { console.log('Get', 0); return 0; }})
Object.defineProperty(testFixture, '1', { get() { console.log('Get', 1); return 1; }})
Object.defineProperty(testFixture, '2', { get() { console.log('Get', 2); return 2; }})

_(testFixture).map(item => item + 1).at(1).value();
```

In that example, it seems like it should be possible to optimize the chain such that only the mapping function for the indexes provided in `at` are executed.  Currently, it looks like the mapping function is executed for all indexes

title: Bug with filtering by String value
Question about the the Roadmap plan on _.each
body:
Now `_.each` is an alias for `_.forEach`. The Roadmap says that `_.each` will end a chain sequence. So two questions are:
1. Does it means that `_.each` become a separate method with slightly different behavior than `_.forEach` or this change is about `_.forEach` (while `_.each` is it alias no matter what)?
2. How would it end chain sequence? Would it still return initial Collection but just not wraped, or it starts to return `undefined` like native `Array.prototype.forEach`?

Thanks

an input parameter value

title: isMatch depends on argument order for arrays.
add parseBool function
body:
_.parseBool (or _.parseBoolean) is a utility designed to receive almost any variable and convert it into a proper boolean.

The most common use-case will be for converting strings such as "yes"/"no" or "true"/"false" into actual booleans.

In the fringe case that a boolean cannot be resolved, the string "NaB" is returned as JS doesn't have an absent boolean equivalent.

title: Missing Documentation in the changelog: _.take is always returning array now
body:
Hi,

I just upgraded from 2.4 to 3.10 and I encountered a change in behaviour that I did not see in the changelog:

``` Javascript
// 2.4
_.take([2,3,4,5])  // 2

// 3.10
_.take([2,3,4,5]) // [2]
```

Not sure where exactly that change was made, I assume from 2.x to 3. but I did not find a comment about it.

It might make sense to add it to the changelog.

title: `_.(...).times(...);` is not working in 3.10.*
body:
1. As [this fiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/W4QfJ/905/) shows: `_(5).times(function() { console.log('hi'); } );` still works in v2.4.2
2. However, as [this fiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/W4QfJ/906/) shows: `_(5).times(function() { console.log('hi'); } );` does not work anymore in v3.10.0

title: TypeError: Cannot read property 'prototype' of undefined at runInContext with stripe module
body:
I am integrating Stripe Api and Authorize.net Api as payment gateways in a Nodejs Web platform. Both of the module use Bluebird library and Lodash Js . While i run the code with correct api key/Secret key infos I am getting error

> TypeError: Cannot read property 'prototype' of undefined at runInContext on (../node_modules/stripe/node_modules/lodash/index.js)
> After some research, I have found a solution by adding 

`if (typeof context.Object !== 'function') context = this;`

But after adding this, another error is generated.

> An error occurred : Cannot read property 'call' of undefined

My current version of nodejs is v4.2.1. The Api keys/ and secret infos is correct, I am not sure what the problem is. Does anyone have any ideas?

title: adding math subtract
_.find doesnt return truthy results
body:
The documentation states "returning the first element predicate returns truthy for".

Using the example in the docs with this array:

``` javascript
var users = [
  { 'user': 'barney',  'age': 36, 'active': true },
  { 'user': 'fred',    'age': 40, 'active': false },
  { 'user': 'pebbles', 'age': 1,  'active': true }
];
```

using find like below, returns undefined, but should return the pebbles object.

``` javascript
_.find(users, { age: '1' })
```

Maybe I am totally wrong about what truthy means, but isnt that when the code below returns true ? 

``` javascript
'1' == 1
```

title: Problem with _.difference
body:
I want to the set difference arrayA - arrayB , but when the arrayA include array, it does not work.
e.g

```
console.log(_.difference([[1]],[[1]]));
// -> [[1]] ,not []
```

I see samevalueszero http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-samevaluezero
seems like `Return true if x and y are the same Object value. Otherwise, return false.`
We alwasy compare two arrays use Array.toString() and compare the string

```
var arrayA = [1], arrayB = [1];
arrayA.toString() === arrayB.toString() // true
arrayA == arrayB //false;
```

How can i get the difference in that times?

title: _.set does not work correctly when a path component is a number
.merge treats a string like an array instead of a scalar value
body:
Expected:

``` js
> require('lodash').merge({a: 'asdf'}, {a: [1, 2]})
{ a: [ 1, 2 ] }
```

Actual:

``` js
> require('lodash').merge({a: 'asdf'}, {a: [1, 2]})
{ a: [ 1, 2, 'd', 'f' ] }
```

title: Enhancement: isFunction( v ) ? v( v, ...args ) : v
body:
(I apologize if this has already been suggested, I couldn't find it in any issue tho...)
## What?

I propose a quite simple addition to lodash, a function that if given a function, calls it with any other arguments, or if given a value, simply returns that value.
## In code:

``` js
/**
 * Returns the value of v called with any additional arguments if _.isFunction(v) holds,
 * otherwise it returns v.
 *
 * @param {*|Function} v  A value, or a function.
 * @param {...*}  args  Any other arguments.
 * @return {*}  v or v(...args).
 */
_.voc = (v, ...args) => isFunction(v) ? v(v, ...args) : v;
```

Perhaps an addition to this could be to bind `this`, but I think this plays bad with `args`.
## Naming

Here are some naming ideas:
- `voc` (`value` or `call`)
- `voi` (`value` or `invoke`)
- `invokeIf`
- `val`
- `value`

title: Enhancement: Identify implicit type conversions that would benefit from `toNumber` consistency

Feature request: function _.isBlank() for all types
body: Function `_.isEmpty` works only for `object`, `array`, `string`, or jQuery-like collection. I faced situation when I had to check if passed value is not empty, however I got `true` for `integer`, `boolean`, `date`, `regexp`, `function`, `infinity`. I know that I can check type of value before using `_.isBlank`, but I'd like something more compact. In addition `date` can be invalid and I have to also check `_.isNaN((new Date('')).getDate())`

title: Question: ufeff or ufffe in tests?
body:
In the tests there is 

```
      // Zero-width space (zws), next line character (nel), and non-character (bom) are not whitespace.
      var problemChars = '\x85\u200b\ufffe',
```

but should it read?

```
      var problemChars = '\x85\u200b\ufeff',
```

just curious about what it is actually testing.

> In UTF-16, a BOM (U+FEFF) may be placed as the first character of a file or character stream to indicate the endianness (byte order) of all the 16-bit code units of the file or stream. If an attempt is made to read this stream with the wrong endianess, the bytes will be swapped, thus delivering the character U+FFFE, which is defined by Unicode as a "non character" that should never appear in the text.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte_order_mark#UTF-16

title: Lazy evaluation on lodash 3.10.1
body:
First, sorry if this is not the right place to make this kind of question.

When I was trying the library on JSBin, I tried to see the lazy evaluation in action by adding some `console.log()` inside the functions. Then, I downloaded the current version (3.10.1), expecting the same behavior. But that wasn't what happened. I realized that JSBin was actually using 3.0.1 version and I, in the other hand, am using the current version of the library. I've searched if there was any configuration or change that was made from the last versions to the current one, but I couldn't find any help.

So, here is my tests:

```
_(_.range(10)).filter((x) => {
  console.log('FILTER: ' + x);
  return x % 2;
}).map((x) => {
  console.log('MAP: ' + x);            
  return x * 2;
}).value();
```

3.0.1 output:

```
"FILTER: 0"
"FILTER: 1"
"MAP: 1"
"FILTER: 2"
"FILTER: 3"
"MAP: 3"
"FILTER: 4"
"FILTER: 5"
"MAP: 5"
"FILTER: 6"
"FILTER: 7"
"MAP: 7"
"FILTER: 8"
"FILTER: 9"
"MAP: 9"
```

3.10.1 output:

```
"FILTER: 0"
"FILTER: 1"
"FILTER: 2"
"FILTER: 3"
"FILTER: 4"
"FILTER: 5"
"FILTER: 6"
"FILTER: 7"
"FILTER: 8"
"FILTER: 9"
"MAP: 1"
"MAP: 3"
"MAP: 5"
"MAP: 7"
"MAP: 9"
```

title: Enhancement: expose isIndex, isLength and complimentary toLength
Enhancement: Use _.toNumber for _.toInteger to benefit from binary and octal parsing, (avoid float subtraction errors, not tested original)
Object.prototype properties conflict with `_.defaults`
body:
I've recently reported this as [an issue in Backbone.js](https://github.com/jashkenas/backbone/issues/3842), but the more I dive in the code the more I think this is actually an issue with lodash.
Consider this simple code:

```
_.defaults({},{watch:true})
```

When executed in Chrome, it returns: `Object {watch: true}` 
When executed in Firefox, it returns: `Object {  }`.
In particular, Firefox reports that  `typeof _.defaults({},{watch:true}).watch` is `"function"`, as the native Object has a method `watch`.

I can see that this is somewhat consistent with other Object.prototype 'magic' functions - for example

```
_.defaults({},{valueOf:true})
```

gives an "empty" object in both Chrome and Firefox.

I think this implementation is not intentional, not intuitive and rarely beneficial to the developer.
My guess is that there is some (unintended?) asymmetry in how arguments of _.defaults are treated, namely that propertyIsEnumerable is not checked for the first argument, but is (implicitly) checked for the others (as the for..in loop extracts only fields which are enumerable).
It looks like the code is iterating over fields of the second argument, (and this is good, and this is why `watch` is considered for merging at all), but then lodash sees that field `watch` is not `undefined` in the first object, so it doesn't override it - I think that this condition should be strengthened to not only being defined, but also being enumerable (in the sense of belonging to the result of `keys()` just as it is required for the second argument).

This issue causes some problems which are difficult to predict in advance - an app which worked just find a few months back, now is completely broken for Firefox users, simply because they added `watch` to the prototype of Object, and now this name is "troublesome".

title: Lodash.com opens mobile version in Opera browser
body:
It seems that some changes happened like a week ago either in Opera browser or in lodash.com page. 

It started to show a mobile responsive page for the documentation in this browser, so everything looks huge, including fonts and tables

title: Null-conditional Operators - call method if object is non-null
body:
Hi All, to avoid having to always do:

``` javascript
if (object_x != null) {
object_x.destroy();
}
```

I instead do:

``` javascript
 _.invoke([object_x], 'destroy');
```

C# has something similar, see https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn986595.aspx:

```
PropertyChanged?.Invoke(e)
```

---

I have yet to run performance tests to see if this is feasible, however just looking at path the code could potentially take in `_.invoke` it seems, I am guessing now, that this might not be optimal.

Is there a better way and less costly way of doing this?

title: Question: testing a mixin against lodash's tests?
body: If I create a mixin that replaces an actual lodash method, for example _.range. Is there a way to easily test this mixin against the standard set of tests, or am I out of luck?

title: Add function to make chains callable with a new value
body:
Add `_().callable()`, which returns a function that executes the actions
of the chain `callable()` was called on its argument.

This enables the passing of chains to functions which take an interatee.

`callable()` works by cloning the wrapper and replacing the first `__wrapped__`
property which is not itself a wrapper with the argument passed to
the function. It then calls `value()` on the resulting wrapper object
and returns the result.

title: Enhancement to thru
body:
I've made a new function for lo-dash and thought i'd share it here in case it's something you might be interested in. If anything it might make sense to enhance `thru` as it's essentially the same but takes additional arguments and passes them to the function. More than happy to PR if it's not bloat.

The main feature is that you can use a normal function without having to use `mixin` for each one. In this example it's named `call`.

``` javascript
_.chain("555 1212-3232")
  .call(removeChars, '-', ' ')
  .call(removeChar, '+')
  .value();
```

In ES6 it looks like this (more verbose in ES5 of course)

``` javascript
function pipesCall(firstParam, func, ...restParams) {
  func(firstParam, ...restParams);
}
```

I ended up using this to implement Elm/Elixir/F# style pipes for a new compile-to JS language that's utilizing Lo-Dash in case you're curious: [RedScript pipes](https://github.com/AdamBrodzinski/RedScript#think-in-pipes-instead-of-nesting-functions),  &  [RedScript LoDash support](https://github.com/AdamBrodzinski/RedScript#built-in-support-for-lo-dash)

title: Enhancement: Development branch for non-breaking PRs?
body: I was thinking that it would be nice if you had a development branch to allow PRs for non-breaking PRs, you know additions to the library that do not cause breaking change but are considered enhancements but wontfix currently, things that you want to see if they become popular/requested. That way contributions could be made that you could later merge into the master. Maybe it already exists somewhere and I just missed it.

title: defaultsDeep() try to mix string characters into array
body:
In lodash 3.10.1, the following test failed:

```
expect(_.defaultsDeep({ src: ['src'] }, { src: 'src' })).to.deep.equal({ src: ['src'] });
```

with the message: 

```
AssertionError: expected { src: [ 'src', 'r', 'c' ] } to deeply equal { src: [ 'src' ] }
```

title: Do not define an anonymous module
body:
Some [AMD loaders like almond don't support anonymous modules](https://github.com/jrburke/almond#incorrect-module-build-no-module-name).

To make lodash work on these environments it is needed to give the module a name.

I could use requirejs optimizer in my build tool to fix this problem, or just include lodash before almond but I could not see a reason to not have this working out-of-box without needs for changing the build tool.

I'm not sure if this is the right fix, neither if this will broke any other AMD loader but I'm opening the pull request for discussion.

cc @tessalt

title: Enhancement: _.uniqueId extended counter range
Lodash wrapper doesn't work properly
body:
Hi.
I try to create lodash collection in this way:

``` javascript
var x = _([]);
```

According to [the documentation](https://lodash.com/docs#_) Javascript Array's method `push()` is still available:

``` javascript
x.push(2);
```

Actually, my created collection is still empty:

``` javascript
console.log(x.toArray());
```

What am I doing wrong?
Thanks a bunch.

title: 'where' behaves differently than underscore - in specific cases causes browser to hang (infinite loop?)
body:
In specific cases when used with Backbone.Relational I have found that using lodash rather than underscore causes the browser to hang indefinitely. My guess is that lodash is caught in a recursive infinite loop when iterating over model attributes that are themselves models.

The test cases are identical except for the loading of underscore/lodash. 

_To actually run the 'where' call you'll need to uncomment the final lines of the javascript._
**In the lodash version, you'll need to force quit your browser, when the final lines uncommented.**

Underscore
http://jsfiddle.net/my6fvvrk/4/

Lodash
http://jsfiddle.net/my6fvvrk/5/

Note that this can readily be solved by switching out `where` on a per-use basis with a simple `filter` method that does the comparisons.

Thanks! I love lodash!

title: Added `toSafeInteger` and tests as discussed â€¦
body: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1552#issuecomment-150225955

title: Number.constrain method to Number section
body:
It would be nice to have with `.inRange` method `.constrain` (or any other name) with common behavior but Number as return value type:

```
function constrain (n, min, max) {
    if (arguments.length == 2) {
        max = min
        min = 0
    }
    if (n < min) 
        return min
    if (n > max) 
        return max
    return n
}
```

```
_.constrain(1, 2, 3) // 2
_.constrain(1, 0, 3) // 1
_.constrain(1, 4, 3) // 3
_.constrain(5, 10)   // 5
_.constrain(-1, 10)  // 0
```

title: Enhancement: _.sort a stable sort algorithm
body: Difference environments implement  different Array#sort algorithms, some of which are stable, some unstable  and some which are stable for certain array lengths. I would like a implementation that is known stable full stop. I have one coded in my personal library that I would be willing to convert for lodash if you are interested.
